24576.name: Miami Beach Park

activities.name: Miami Beach Park
activities.description: Situated on the beautiful Chesapeake Bay the park features a pavilion, grills, playground and a nature trail. The pavilion is available on a first come, first serve basis and not available for group reservations. To reserve areas at other Baltimore County Parks contact the local community office.

24576.description: Situated on the beautiful Chesapeake Bay the park features a pavilion, grills, playground and a nature trail. The pavilion is available on a first come, first serve basis and not available for group reservations. To reserve areas at other Baltimore County Parks contact the local community office.

24577.name: Northwest Regional Park

activities.name: Northwest Regional Park
activities.description: Paved stroller-friendly paths, and trails with natural surfaces traverse wooded areas of the park and offer walkers, bicyclers, and skaters a chance to get back to nature.

24577.directions: Directions from points east of the intersection of I-795 and I-695:<br />From the Baltimore Beltway (I-695) take exit 19 for I-795 towards Owings Mills. Continue on I-795 for approximately 3 miles and take exit 4 for Owings Mills Boulevard south towards the Owings Mills Town Center. Stay on Owings Mills Boulevard until its end at Lyons Mill Road and make a right. Proceed on Lyons Mill Road for approximately 1.8 miles and make a right onto Deer Park Road. The park entrance, marked with a sign, will be just ahead on the right.
24577.description: The eastern portion Northwest Regional Park, which consisted almost entirely of open fields at the time of acquisition, was recently developed with a variety of recreational facilities for the use of the community and local recreation councils. The baseball and softball programs of the recreation councils will be well served by the park's four ball diamonds, which encircle a central gazebo and feature home run fences and warning tracks. A lighted artificial turf and two irrigated athletic fields help to demand for field sports such as soccer, lacrosse, and football. The largest portion of Northwest Regional Park, which is largely wooded, is situated on the west side of Deer Park Road north of Lyons Mill Road. This area is predominantly natural, featuring a stretch of the Locust Run stream, a County-designated recreational greenway.

4098.name: Plantation Trail

activities.name: Plantation Trail
activities.description: Plantation Trail features 8 miles of hiking trails near Davis, WV.

4098.directions: Best access if off Rt. 32 about 3 miles south of Davis, WV.  Trail is marked well. <br />Runs from Rt.32 through the middle of Canaan Loop Rd. and comes out on Canaan Loop Rd. at the far end.   Several options are available when riding Plantation by using the Fire Trails #3 and #6, Daivs Trail (Allegheny Trail), Lindy Trail, Railroad Grade Trail and Canaan Loop Rd. (Forest Service Rd. #13).<br /><br />This trail is a true XC trail, not manicured singletrack.   That in mind,  this trail is not for the light hearted.  It has every obstacle one can think of including rocks, roots, stream crossings, rocks, roots, logs, rocks, roots, steeps, and mountain laurel so tight you'll have scratches on your arms to prove you were there.  Oh and did I mention rocks?  And how about mud !  Yep, it's there too.

3755.name: First Landing State Park

activities.name: First Landing State Park
activities.description: First Landing State Park features 12 miles of hiking trails near Virginia Beach, VA.

3755.directions: I-264 east to exit 19B for LYNNHAVEN PKWY.  Turn RIGHT onto US-58 E / VIRGINIA BEACH BLVD.  Turn LEFT onto GREAT NECK RD N.  Turn SLIGHT RIGHT onto US-60 / SHORE DR.  Right at First Landing State Park<br />2500 Shore Drive, Virginia Beach, VA 23451, US.  The entrance to park is on both sides of road, take Right entrance.

26628.name: Stout's Point Overlook (Arkansas)

activities.name: Stout's Point Overlook (Arkansas)
activities.description: Stout's Point Overlook - From this point, you can view the Arkansas River, Lock and Dam #9, Blue Point, and Ada Valley. An elevated, barrier-free walkway including wayside exhibits has views from different points around Stout's Point. Legend tells of the young French girl who disguised herself as a cabin boy so she could secretly accompany her fiancée to the "New World". Petit Jean became fatally ill and requested to be buried here.

26628.directions: 1285 Petit Jean Mountain Road - Morrilton, AR 72110 / Phone: (501) 727-5441

6149.name: Assateague Island National Seashore

activities.name: Assateague Island National Seashore
activities.description:
Experience life on a barrier island! Assateague Island has a variety of paved and unpaved trails open for hiking. There are also 37 miles of beach to wander.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6149.directions: There are two entrances to Assateague Island National Seashore. Assateague's north entrance is at the end of Route 611, eight miles south of Ocean City, MD. The south entrance is at the end of Route 175, two miles from Chincoteague, VA. There is no vehicle access between the two entrances on Assateague Island. Vehicles must return to the mainland to access either the north or south entrance.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6150.name: Catoctin Mountain Park

activities.name: Catoctin Mountain Park
activities.description:
The east side of the park features stunning vistas, challenging terrain, and access to Cunningham Falls. Most trailheads begin at the visitor center. Parking and trailheads are also available by the park headquarters and at three points along Park Central Road.<br />
The west side of the park is the wilder side. Adventurous hikers are more likely to see wildlife, wetlands, and an up-close view of nature. Remnants of former farms dot the land. The park's picnic areas, campgrounds, and back-country shelters connect with the trails.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6150.directions: Street Address of the Visitor Center is 14707 Park Central Road, Thurmont, MD<br /><br />From Washington DC take the George Washington Memorial Parkway north to I495 beltway to I270 north 27 miles to Frederick, MD. Take Route 15 17 miles north to Thurmont, MD. Take Route 77 West, the exit sign is marked Catoctin Mountain Park. Travel approximately 3 miles west on 77 and turn right onto Park Central Road. The Visitor Center is on the right.<br /><br />From Baltimore, MD Take I695 beltway to I70 West to Frederick, MD. Take Route 15 North to Thurmont, MD. Take Route 77 West (the exit sign says Catoctin Mountain Park. Travel approximately 3 miles west on 77 and turn right onto Park Central Road. The Visitor Center is on the right.<br /><br />From Hagerstown, MD I70 east to Route 66 north for seven miles to right on Route 64 for 1 mile to right onto Route 77 East at a traffic light. Continue on Route 77 East for approximately 7 miles. Turn left onto Park Central Road and the Visitor Center is on the right.<br /><br />From Gettysburg, PA Route 15 south. In Thurmont, MD, exit onto Route 77 West(the exit sign says Catoctin Mountain Park, go approximately 3 miles, turn right onto Park Central Road and the Visitor Center is on the right. <br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6151.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park

activities.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
activities.description:
Hiking and biking along the towpath are excellent ways to see the park. Hiker-Biker Campsites are located from Swain's Lock to Cumberland. Several park areas have interpretive trails and other hiking opportunities.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6151.directions: The Great Falls Tavern Visitor Center is located at 11710 MacArthur Blvd., Potomac, MD 20854<br /><br />Brunswick Visitor Center is located at 40 West Potomac Street Brunswick, MD 21716<br /><br />Ferry Hill Place is located at 16500 Sharspburg Pike, MD<br /><br />The Williamsport Visitor Center is located at the Cushwa Basin, 205 W. Potomac St., Williamsport, MD 21795<br /><br />439 East Main Street, Hancock, MD 21750<br /><br />Cumberland, MD 21502 (301-722-8226)<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6152.name: Fort Washington Park

activities.name: Fort Washington Park
activities.description:
Fort Washington Park has a wide variety of activities. There is a 3-mile trail that follows the perimeter of the park boundary, offering the opportunity for wildlife viewing. Birdwatchers enjoy the quite solitude of the park to find that one special bird. If fishing is for you, the park is located right along the Potomac River where there are many different types of fish waiting for you.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6152.directions: From I-95/495 take exit 3, Indian Head Higway South/MD 210.  Travel about 4 miles to Fort Washington Road, turn right.  The park is located at the end of the road.<br /><br />From Waldorf, MD: MD228 to Indian Head Highway/MD210 North.  Turn left onto Old Fort Road.  Continue to end of road, at the stop sign turn left onto Fort Washington Road, continue to park entrance.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6153.name: Greenbelt Park

activities.name: Greenbelt Park
activities.description:
The park offers activities for the naturalist and casual visitor, and it has a conveniently located campground for visitors to the Nation's Capital. Greenbelt Park is an oasis where you can relax in an exceptional outdoor setting and over 10 miles of trails.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6153.directions: Off I-95 South<br /><br />Take Exit 23 Route 201 Kenilworth Avenue South(toward Bladensburg). (this will be a left). Drive on Kenilworth Avenue (Route 201). Once crossing over I-95, you will see sign for Route 193 Greenbelt Road. Veer right to Take Route 193 East.<br /><br />Take a left on Greenbelt Road .<br /><br />(Greenbelt Road is Route 193 and is an overpass over Route 201) <br /><br />The park entrance is a quarter mile on the right hand side of Greenbelt Road across from Fridays restaurant and Marriott Courtyard.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6154.name: Oxon Cove Park & Oxon Hill Farm

activities.name: Oxon Cove Park & Oxon Hill Farm
activities.description:
Venture beyond the hilltop and explore part of Oxon Cove Park's 512 acres by strolling along the lower fields or riding the bike path along Oxon Cove.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6154.directions: From the Capital Beltway (I-495/I-95) in Maryland:Stay in the local lanes and take exit 3 (MD-210 Indian Head Highway).  At the light make a left onto MD-210 Indian Head Highway south.  Stay to your right and take the first exit to MD-414 Oxon Hill Road/ toward I-495/I-95.  When you come to the stop light go straight onto Bald Eagle Road.  Follow this road into our parking lot. <br /><br />From the Capital Beltway (I-495/I-95) in Virginia:Stay in the thru lanes and take exit 3B (MD-210 Indian Highway north) towards Forest Heights.  Take a right at the stop light onto Oxon Hill Road west.  Do not take the exit for MD-210 Indian Head Highway north.  At the second stop light make a right onto Bald Eagle Road.  Follow this road into our parking lot.<br /><br />From Washington, D.C.:Take I-295 south toward Maryland.  Follow I-295 until it ends at I-495/I-95 and MD-210 Indian Head Highway.  Take the exit for MD-210 Indian Head Highway; take the first ramp towards 210-Indian Head Highway north towards Forest Heights.  At the second stop light make a right onto MD-414 Oxon Hill Road east.  At the next light make a left onto Bald Eagle Road.  Follow this road into our parking lot.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

4107.name: Red Run Trail

activities.name: Red Run Trail
activities.description: Red Run Trail features 2 miles of hiking trails near Slatyfork, WV.

4107.directions: This trail is only 2.5 miles long and runs between Gauley Mountain Trail and Right Fork Trail off the Highland Scenic Hwy. Rt.150 in Pocahontas County WV, a few miles south of Slatyfork and 8 miles north of Marlinton, WV.   Take Rt.219 south from Elkins or North From Marlinton and get on Rt.150.  If you come across Rt.39 from Summersville, through Richwood, turn onto Rt.150 at the Cranberry Visitors Center.  Go to Little Laurel Overlook near the top of Gauley Mountain and park there.

24588.name: Central Perkiomen Valley Park

activities.name: Central Perkiomen Valley Park
activities.description: Central Perkiomen Valley Park headquarters on Plank Road is situated along the scenic Perkiomen Creek in the center of Montgomery County. This 800-acre park extends over 10 municipalities, offering a wide variety of family activities. Visitors can enjoy a children's playground as well as vistas of the Perkiomen Creek while fishing. Picnic tables and grills are available throughout the park's picnic grove. There is one large pavilion available by reservation for large groups. Nearby are recreational offerings of volleyball, shuffleboard and restroom facilities. For special occasions, the Park's Old Mill House is available by reservation. Visitors can walk, jog, bike or horseback ride on over 19 miles of the Perkiomen Trail winding along the Perkiomen Creek. Central Perkiomen Valley Park is an alcohol free park. Park Hours are from 6:00 a.m. - sunset, daily.

24588.description: Central Perkiomen Valley Park headquarters on Plank Road is situated along the scenic Perkiomen Creek in the center of Montgomery County. This 800-acre park extends over 10 municipalities, offering a wide variety of family activities. Visitors can enjoy a children's playground as well as vistas of the Perkiomen Creek while fishing. Picnic tables and grills are available throughout the park's picnic grove. There is one large pavilion available by reservation for large groups. Nearby are recreational offerings of volleyball, shuffleboard and restroom facilities. For special occasions, the Park's Old Mill House is available by reservation. Visitors can walk, jog, bike or horseback ride on over 19 miles of the Perkiomen Trail winding along the Perkiomen Creek. Central Perkiomen Valley Park is an alcohol free park. Park Hours are from 6:00 a.m. - sunset, daily.

24589.name: Green Lane Park

activities.name: Green Lane Park
activities.description: Green Lane Park, in northwestern Montgomery County, offers a variety of year-round, outdoor activities and programs for people to choose from. Park visitors can enjoy fishing, boating (including boat rentals), family and group camping, picnicking, 25 miles of trails for horseback riding, mountain biking and hiking, as well as two children's playgrounds. Winter enthusiasts can cross-country ski, ice fish or go ice skating. The park also offers summer concerts and movies, and family-oriented, environmental education programs on weekends.  Park Hours are 6:00 am-sunset, daily.

24589.description: Green Lane Park, in northwestern Montgomery County, offers a variety of year-round, outdoor activities and programs for people to choose from. Park visitors can enjoy fishing, boating (including boat rentals), family and group camping, picnicking, 25 miles of trails for horseback riding, mountain biking and hiking, as well as two children's playgrounds. Winter enthusiasts can cross-country ski, ice fish or go ice skating. The park also offers summer concerts and movies, and family-oriented, environmental education programs on weekends.  Park Hours are 6:00 am-sunset, daily.

24590.name: Lorimer Park

activities.name: Lorimer Park
activities.description: New to the facility, a 1.8 mile section of the former Fox Chase-Newtown rail line has been converted to a recreational trail. This crushed stone path provides level hiking and biking, and views of the creek valley along the entire western edge of the park. Open daily 8 am to sunset.

24590.description: This 230 acre oasis of woods and meadows, in the suburbs of eastern Abington Township, attracts visitors to its natural beauty year-round. A bequest from the late George Horace Lorimer, former Editor-in-Chief of The Saturday Evening Post, Lorimer Park is a haven for wildlife under a canopy of huge trees. Activities include hiking, picnicking, bird and animal watching, horseback riding (with your own horse), and, in the winter, sledding and cross-country skiing.

18448.name: Palmetto Loop Trail (Florida)

activities.name: Palmetto Loop Trail
activities.description: The Marshall Hampton Reserve encompasses 1,173 acres and offers more 6 miles in 3 trail systems

18448.directions: Palmetto Loop Trail @ Marshall Hampton Reserve, 3125 Thornhill Road, Winter Haven, Florida 33880  It's located near the intersection of SR 540 & Thornhill Rd, south of Auburndale and southeast of the Polk Parkway. Take I-4 heading West towards Tampa take exit 41 onto Expwy 540 to exit 14 turn left to Thornhill Road turn right.

24593.name: Upper Schuylkill Valley Park

activities.name: Upper Schuylkill Valley Park
activities.description: The Schuylkill River in Upper Providence Township forms a natural backdrop to this 15-acre display of wild animals and raptors indigenous to Pennsylvania. Picnicking and fishing are popular along the river, and a short, scenic hike will lead you to the Schuylkill Canal Park in Mont Clare.

24593.description: The Schuylkill River in Upper Providence Township forms a natural backdrop to this 15-acre display of wild animals and raptors indigenous to Pennsylvania. Picnicking and fishing are popular along the river, and a short, scenic hike will lead you to the Schuylkill Canal Park in Mont Clare.

26642.name: South Kaibab Trail

activities.name: South Kaibab Trail
activities.description:
Hikers seeking panoramic views unparalleled on any other trail at Grand Canyon will want to consider a hike <br />
down the South Kaibab Trail. It is the only trail at Grand Canyon National Park that so dramatically holds true to a <br />
ridgeline descent. But this exhilarating sense of exposure to the vastness of the canyon comes at a cost: there is <br />
little shade and no water for the length of this trail. During winter months, the constant sun exposure is likely to <br />
keep most of the trail relatively free of ice and snow. For those who insist on hiking during summer months, which <br />
is not recommended in general, this trail is the quickest way to the bottom (it has been described as "a trail in a <br />
hurry to get to the river"), but due to lack of any water sources, ascending the trail can be a dangerous <br />
proposition.<br />
<br />
When camping at Bright Angel Campground, many hikers prefer to hike down the South Kaibab Trail and <br />
up the Bright Angel Trail. Though the South Kaibab Trail has an almost identical maximum grade <br />
compared to the Bright Angel, it is more consistently sloped but does not have water or shade. The hike <br />
down South Kaibab Trail typically takes 4-6 hours. <br />
<br />
The trail begins with a series of tight switchbacks. This is where ice will most likely be encountered during <br />
the winter months. After these initial switchbacks, the trail traverses below Yaki Point to the aptly named <br />
Ooh Ah Point (the first panoramic view of the canyon). From Ooh Ah Point on, the trail follows the top of a <br />
ridgeline and is consequently without shade. Several broad and steeply-plunging switchbacks later, hikers <br />
reach Cedar Ridge. There are pit toilets at Cedar Ridge, but no water or emergency phone. <br />
<br />
From Cedar Ridge, the South Kaibab Trail traverses below O'Neill Butte without a single switchback to <br />
Skeleton Point. At three miles from the rim, Skeleton Point is the maximum distance recommended for a <br />
day hike. The trail goes directly off the end of Skeleton Point and here, where the trail has been blasted <br />
directly out of the limestone cliffs, hikers will encounter the most dramatic sense of exposure. The trail <br />
descends rapidly via a series of switchbacks to the Tonto Platform and Tipoff. There are pit toilets and an <br />
emergency phone at Tipoff, but no water. For hikers who will be utilizing the Tonto Trail to the east or <br />
west, the intersection is located fifty feet or so up-trail from the pit toilets. <br />
<br />
Below Tipoff, the South Kaibab Trail loosely follows the course of an earlier trail called the Cable Trail <br />
(built in 1907 to accommodate access to the old cable car system across the river that existed before <br />
construction of the present suspension bridge). Vestiges of this earlier trail can be seen as the South <br />
Kaibab Trail descends toward the Colorado River. Access to Bright Angel Campground is via the black <br />
bridge (built in 1921).

26642.directions: The South Kaibab Trail is located near Yaki Point in the Grand Canyon National Park. Due to the popularity of this area and extremely limited <br /><br />space, parking is not permitted at the trailhead. Hikers must use the park's free shuttle bus system to <br /><br />reach the trailhead. Every morning, several hiker express buses leave from the Bright Angel Lodge and <br /><br />then from the Backcountry Information Center (times vary depending on the month). Otherwise, hikers will <br /><br />need to take the village bus (Blue Line) to Canyon View Information Plaza and transfer to the Green Line. <br /><br />South Kaibab trailhead is the first stop on the Green Line.

18452.name: Merritt Island Wildlife Refuge (Florida) Visitor Center Boardwalk

activities.name: Merritt Island Wildlife Refuge Visitor Center Boardwalk
activities.description: Merritt Island National Wildlife Refuge was established in 1963 as an overlay of NASA's John F. Kennedy Space Center. Consisting of 140,000 acres, the Refuge provides a wide variety of habitats: coastal dunes, saltwater estuaries and marshes, freshwater impoundments, scrub, pine flatwoods, and hardwood hammocks provide habitat for more than 1,500 species of plants and animals

18452.directions: Address: P.O. Box 6504. Titusville, FL, FL 32782. Phone: 407-861-0667 ...<br /><br /><br /><br />Visitor Center Hours<br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br />The Visitor Information Center is open 7 days a week, from 8:00 am to 4:30 weekdays and 9:00 am until 5:00 pm on weekends from November - March. The Center is closed on Sundays from April - October. The Center is closed most federal holidays, but will remain open normal business hours on Martin Luther King Jr. Day and President's Day in 2013. All other refuge areas are open during daylight hours.

4117.name: Seneca Creek Trail

activities.name: Seneca Creek Trail
activities.description: Seneca Creek Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Spruce Knob, WV.

4117.directions: This trail is located off Forest Service 112 near the base of Spruce Mountain below Spruce Knob.  This trail is most often used as a return trail after making a loop on other trail and used to be an old, old railroad grade (looks like some double track and some single track).  At 3.5 miles to the termination at Judy Springs pack in camping area it make a good 7 miles for beginners if ridden out and back.  You can get 14 to 20 + mile loops using this trail.  Many of the other trails in the area are singletrack.  Overall Rating is considering loop and the return trip on Seneca Creek Trail.

6148.name: Antietam National Battlefield

activities.name: Antietam National Battlefield
activities.description:
The Bloodiest One Day Battle in American History<br />
<br />
23,000 soldiers were killed, wounded or missing after twelve hours of savage combat on September 17, 1862. The Battle of Antietam ended the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia's first invasion into the North and led to Abraham Lincoln's issuance of the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation.<br />
The Park offers six self guided totaling about eight miles.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6148.directions: The Visitor Center address is:<br /><br />5831 Dunker Church Road, Sharpsburg, MD 21782<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

18458.name: Francis S. Taylor WMA

activities.name: Francis S. Taylor WMA
activities.description: While there are no official hiking trails within the Wildlife Management Area the levees offer endless possibilities with endless views of the Everglades.

18458.directions: Main entrance is 10 miles east of Turnpike at US41/SR90.

activities.name: Lookout Tower Trail
activities.description: Great trail for families and kids.  Starts out with a paved entrance and quickly leads to a wooded trail and the lookout view point.  The rest of the trail follows the edge of the reservoir.

4125.name: North Fork Mountain Trail

activities.name: North Fork Mountain Trail
activities.description: North Fork Mountain Trail features 24 miles of hiking trails near Petersburg Or Franklin, Wv, WV.

4125.directions: a few possibilities on starting points.. most people run a shuttle since it is a ridge trail running 24 miles!  There are a few trails spurring off it on the northern half, like Redman Run, Landis trail and forest rd 79 (north half is the all single track half)  Those can be used to make a loop if you like to do alot of climbing. If you despise climbing, consider doing with a shuttle because you rack up a fair amount of climbing on the ridge trail alone.

4101.name: Bear Pen (modified) Loop

activities.name: Bear Pen (modified) Loop
activities.description: Bear Pen (modified) Loop features 17 miles of hiking trails near Slatyfork, WV.

4101.directions: Take US219 south of Elkins past the Snowshoe turn off, through Slatyfork about 1.6 miles south of Bechwith Lumber Company, to Mine Rd. (FR24). Take a right on Mine Rd. and go 4 miles to the Tea Creek Trail parking area.  Note, you will pass Gauley Mountain Trail on your left just before reaching Tea Creek Trail Parking. This is a good place to begin if you don't mind 7 to 8 miles of slightly uphill gravel road for the end of your ride. If you would rather ride some of those road miles before the singletrack, go past Tea Creek parking, then left on FR135 and drive to a nice wide spot a couple miles down this hill, at least down the long grade.   Park there and then bike back up FR135, go right on Mine Rd., ride past Tea Creek trailhead to Gauley Mountain Trail and your singletrack begins.  Note, near the end of your ride on FR135 there is a awesome reflective pond on your right.  Be sure to check it out.  See pictures.  Please don't spend any money at ERTC or Snowshoe since they now support wilderness designation which closes trails to mountain bikes.

6178.name: Three Lakes WMA

activities.name: Three Lakes WMA
activities.description:
The Three Lake WMA is contained in two sections with the Prairie Lakes unit in the middle of them. There are three designated campsites within the Three Lakes WMA. The Florida Trail runs through the WMA from its intersection with SR60 at the south, through the Prairie Lakes Unit, up to where it leaves the area at US 441. The majority of this area is geared towards hunting, with more campsite and observation towers in the Prairie Lakes Unit. Use caution during general gun season. <br />
<br />
See Three Lakes WMA - Prairie Lakes Unit for specific information on that area.<br />
<br />
FWC site: http://myfwc.com/viewing/recreation/wmas/lead/three-lakes/visitor-information/

6178.directions: Southern entrance is on SR60 14.5 miles west of Yeehaw Junction. Northern entrance is on US 441 13.5 miles south of Holopaw. Middle entrance is on CR523 25 miles south of St. Cloud and 9 miles north of Kenansville.

18467.name: Art Loeb Nat'l Recreational Trail

activities.name: Art Loeb Nat'l Recreational Trail
activities.description:
Once you cross the Davidson River you climb steeply to Shut-In Ridge. Then the trail takes you up & down knobs, along ridges & down into several gaps. Points of interest include ridge top views of Cedar Rock Mountain & Butter Gap Shelter, where there is a spring near by, as well as Pilot Mountain, Shining Rock, and Black Balsam Knob.<br />
About 4 miles up from Daniel Boone Boyscout Camp, there is also a 1 mile trail that leads to the top of Cold Mountain. The trail ends at the Daniel Boone Boyscout Camp on the Little East Fork Pigeon River.

18467.directions: From the Ranger Station turn Left on US 276, go about 1/4 mile to Davidson River Campground. Turn Right onto the access road, then immediately turn Left & park at the Art Loeb trailhead

activities.name: Fox Island
activities.description: http://allencountyparks.org/parks/fox-island/

activities.name: Appalachian Trail: Pennsylvania
activities.description:
The Appalachian Trail runs for 231 miles through the state of Pennsylvania, on its way from Georgia to Maine. It runs from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3301/Maryland/Appalachian-Trail--Maryland.html">Maryland</a> border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/Hiking-Trails/New-Jersey_34.html">New Jersey</a> border. <br />
If you are looking for detailed information about each section of the AT in PA, please click on the individual section listings below.

14374.name: Lehigh Gorge State Park

activities.name: Lehigh Gorge State Park
activities.description: 4,548 acre Lehigh Gorge State Park is home to the Lehigh River and the surrounding gorge, as well as many great hiking trails. Click on the individual trail listings below for more detailed information about each one.

14374.directions: Go north on PA-903 out of Jim Thorpe and cross the Lehigh River. There is a sharp left turn right after the bridge. After this when 903 turns right go straight until you see the Glen Onoko access road. Turn left to go to the trail head. It a little back the access road until you get to the end by Glen Onoko Falls.

18097.name: Hacklebarney State Park

activities.name: Hacklebarney State Park
activities.description: Hiking trails in the northern portions of the 465-acre natural area offer breathtaking views of the Black River, which lies deep within a shaded hemlock ravine. Rinehart and Trout Brooks empty into the Black river and several small waterfalls can be seen from the high trails. The diversity of upland and wetland habitats provides excellent birdwatching opportunities, especially during migration, Since the topography of the park is rather rugged, comfortable walking shoes are recommended.

18097.directions: Route 206 to Chester. Follow Route 24/513 west for one mile to State Park Road for two miles. Turn right onto Hacklebarney Road and travel 1/2 mile. The entrance is on the left.
18097.description: The freshwater Black River briskly cuts its way through rocky Hacklebarney State Park, cascading around boulders in the hemlock-lined ravine. Two tributaries, Rinehart and Trout Brooks, also course their way through this glacial valley, feeding the Black River. Even in the heat of midsummer, the temperature of Black River gorge is cool and refreshing. Today Hacklebarney is a favorite place for avid anglers, hikers and picnickers, yet in the 19th century the park was a mined iron ore site. The gushing river against the grey boulders and dark green hemlocks creates a majestic beauty in any season. Three rare and endangered plant species exist within the park: American ginseng, leatherwood and Virginia pennywort. Over a hundred bird species and wildlife such as black bear, woodchuck, deer and fox live in the park.

activities.name: Appalachian Trail: New York
activities.description: The Appalachian Trail runs for 90 miles through the state of New York, from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3306/New-Jersey/Appalachian-Trail--New-Jersey.html">New Jersey</a> border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/Hiking-Trails/Connecticut_10.html">Connecticut</a> border. To get additional information, click on the listings form the individual sections of the trail below.

activities.name: Lee State Park
activities.description: Lee State Park, which sits along the Lynches river, is home to several different hiking trails. Click on the individual trail listings below for more detailed information about each one.

4093.name: Kennison Mountain Trail

activities.name: Kennison Mountain Trail
activities.description: Kennison Mountain Trail features 9 miles of hiking trails near Richwood, WV.

4093.directions: Only using part of Kennison Mtn. Trail for this loop.  Not recommended for XC beginners.  Intermediate riders should be able to enjoy this trail and learn some new skills.  A little over 1/2 this loop is singletrack, the other half, fire roads.<br />Kennison Mtn. Trail actually starts off Pocahontas Trail a couple miles west of the Cranberry Visitors Center and crosses Rt.39 and will take you all the way to the Cranberry River. (Note: no crossing at the Cranberry - Thigh deep ford only to the Cranberry River Trail).  That is why loop is recommended.

4104.name: Cvi Trails

activities.name: Cvi Trails
activities.description: Cvi Trails features 15 miles of hiking trails near Davis, WV.

4104.directions: If coming south on Rt.32, drive through the quaint little town of Davis, WV. and go straight through (left) at the "Y" intersection where Rt.32 crosses a new highway bridge.  You will see a grocery store there, stay to the left of it on a small blacktop road.  As you go behind the grocery store you will cross a narrow bridge onto a gravel road (Camp 70 Rd.)  Within 200 feet there is a parking area and two of the trails begin here.  The one you are looking at starts out as an old double track that is nearly singletrack.   There is another trail that comes out on your left just before the parking area.   If you are coming from Canaan Valley, turn right at the first intersection after crossing the new highway bridge coming into Davis.  Be sure to stop in a check out Blackwater Bikes on the main street in town (Rt.32)  They have played a big part in building these and many other trails in the area, so if you want to know the latest trail info, stop in an chat with Roger.  If you like to camp but don't like the primative camping on Camp 70 Rd., go toward Blackwater Falls SP, there is a private campground just a 1/10th mile up that road and there is a nice campground in Blackwater Falls, both with services.

activities.name: Appalachian Trail: West Virginia
activities.description:
The Appalachian Trail runs for 20 miles through the state of West Virginia, from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3332/Virginia/Appalachian-Trail--Virginia.html">Virginia</a> border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/Hiking-Trails/Maryland_24.html">Maryland</a> border. <br />
Click on the section listings below for additional information.

6203.name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

activities.name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
activities.description: The Delaware River is the primary focus of recreational activity in the park with canoeing and kayaking, boating, fishing, and swimming. In addition, the recreation area offers more 100 miles of hiking trails, including more than 27 miles of the Appalachian Trail.

6203.directions: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area is located within an hour and a half drive of the New York City and Philadelphia metropolitan areas. It is about 2 1/2 hours drive from the park to Pennsylvania Dutch Country.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6204.name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

activities.name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
activities.description: The Delaware River is the primary focus of recreational activity in the park with canoeing and kayaking, boating, fishing, and swimming. In addition, the recreation area offers more 100 miles of hiking trails, including more than 27 miles of the Appalachian Trail.

6204.directions: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area is located within an hour and a half drive of the New York City and Philadelphia metropolitan areas. It is about 2 1/2 hours drive from the park to Pennsylvania Dutch Country.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6206.name: Morristown National Historical Park

activities.name: Morristown National Historical Park
activities.description:
There are over 13 miles of trails within the park for hiking and horse back riding park trails are open from 8:00 a.m. until approximately a half hour before sunset. Please check entrance signs for times as they change with teh season.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6206.directions: From Interstate 287 South or North:<br /><br />Take Exit 30B (Bernardsville. At the traffic light, turn right onto Route 202 North. Turn left at light for Tempe Wick Road (Route 646). (Note that road has a different name on the right side, don't let this confuse you.) Continue on Tempe Wick Road for about another 1 ½ miles. The entrance to the Jockey Hollow unit of Morristown National Historical Park will be on your right.

22594.name: Table Mountain

activities.name: Table Mountain
activities.description: A moderate 12 mile round trip hike with several stream crossings to then reach the summit of Table Mountain (11,106 ft)

22594.directions: Access the trailhead on the Idaho side of the Tetons to Alta Wyoming. The trailhead begins in Teton Canyon.

18102.name: Kittatinny Valley State Park

activities.name: Kittatinny Valley State Park
activities.description: Trails in the park vary in difficulty and terrain from the gravel roads that are walked and biked by many to the technical terrain enjoyed by hard-core mountain bikers. Single track trails and gravel roads are suitable for hiking, mountain biking, cross-country skiing, snowshoeing, and horseback riding. A 2-mile self-guided nature trail provides a brief introduction to the park's natural and cultural resources. Motorized vehicles are not permitted on any park trails.

18102.directions: To the park office: From Route 80, take Route 206 north approximately 8 miles through Andover Borough. Turn right onto Goodale Road and follow it approx.  1 mile to the park entrance on the right.
18102.description:
Glacial lakes, limestone outcroppings, former railroads, and a small airport are features of Kittatinny Valley State Park. Lake Aeroflex and Gardner's Pond form part of the headwaters of the Pequest River and are excellent for fishing and boating. This scenic property is home to a variety of wildlife such as whitetail deer, wild turkey, a variety of songbirds, beaver, muskrats, and squirrels.

Hunting, hiking, mountain biking, birding, and horseback riding are popular activities. The four lakes offer fishing, boating, and kayaking opportunities.

The Paulinskill Valley Trail and the Sussex Branch Trail are former railroads that have been converted for use as multiple use trails. Both railroads were critical to the development of Sussex County through the late 1800's and early 1900's. The wide cinder surface is ideal for walking, running, mountain biking, and horseback riding. When snow conditions are abundant, these trails provide and excellent opportunity for cross-country skiing, and snowshoeing. You might even see a musher and his dogsled team running down the trail!

4108.name: Dolly Sods North (while Available)

activities.name: Dolly Sods North (while Available)
activities.description: Dolly Sods North (while Available) features 30 miles of hiking trails near Canaan Valley, WV.

4108.directions: Take Rt.32 south out of Davis WV, when you get to the long straight-a-way in Canaan Valley, turn left on Freeland Rd. just before Canaan Valley State Park.  If coming from Harman, north on Rt.32, go just past Canaan Valley State Park and turn right on Freeland Rd.  Follow this road till you come to gravel.  Take the gravel road for about 60 feet and park on your right if you don't mind about a 2.1 mile climb on the gravel road.  If you wish to cut out that climb you can go part way up the mountain and park or all the way to the top and park.  The trail system starts just after the gravel road ends at some large mudholes.   Pick up a map at Blackwater bikes before entering the area.  There are numerous trails all interconnected making numerous routes to ride.  A must do is Rocky Ridge Trail which takes you up on the ridge overlooking Canaan Valley.

6219.name: Blue Ridge Parkway

activities.name: Blue Ridge Parkway: Virginia
activities.description:
The Parkway offers 100 trails ranging from short "leg-stretcher" walks to the Appalachian Trail. <br />
Source: National Park Service

6219.directions: The Parkway connects Shenandoah National Park near Waynesboro, VA (Milepost 0) with Great Smoky Mountains National Park near Cherokee, NC (Milepost 469).  There are entrances and exits at all major federal and state highways and part of a Parkway experience is getting into the towns and communities of the region.  Asheville and Boone, NC and Roanoke, VA are the largest cities along the way.  In Virginia, Interstates 64, 81, and 77 all have directions for accessing the Parkway.  The same is true for Interstates 40 and 26 in North Carolina.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6223.name: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site

activities.name: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site
activities.description:
The Thomas Hariot Nature Trail offers a 20-minute pocket wilderness experience of the island's natural setting. Wayside signs on the trail relate what English explorers observed of the natural resources and the commodities that could be made from them.<br />
The Freedom Trail leads 1¼ miles from the nearby Elizabethan Gardens through the park land to the island's western edge, offering a viewshed that the native Algonquians enjoyed from their island home.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6223.directions: From the North via Norfolk, VA take US-168 South or US-17 South to US158 East to US-64/264 West. The park is located on Roanoke Island, 3 Miles north of the town of Manteo, NC.<br /><br />From the West, approach Roanoke Island using US-64 East from Raleigh, NC. The park is located on Roanoke Island, 3 miles North of Manteo, NC.<br /><br />From the South, approach Roanoke Island using I-95 to Rocky Mount, NC then use US-64 East. The park is located on Roanoke Island, 3 Miles north of Manteo, NC.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

4110.name: Laurel Creek Trail At Rimel Wv

activities.name: Laurel Creek Trail At Rimel Wv
activities.description: Laurel Creek Trail At Rimel Wv features 9 miles of hiking trails near Marlinton, WV.

4110.directions: Take Rt.39 east from Marlinton, WV and not far after passing through Minnehaha Springs start watching on the left for a sign noting picnic area on your left (Rimel National Forest Recreation area).  If you reach Rt.92 south intersection you just passed it.  Park at the picnic area and look to the right of the map display and you will the the both ends of the trail.

8281.name: Stonewall Jackson Lake

activities.name: Stonewall Jackson Lake
activities.description:
A major recreation area is located at the Stonewall Jackson State Park which provides visitors with numerous opportunities including a 374 slip marina, picnic facilities and a 18 hole championship golf course, lodge, cabins and additional campsites. Backwater areas provide excellent fishing opportunities. Canoeists and other paddlers can explore the many inlets and backwater areas along the lake's 82-mile shoreline.

Trails extend throughout this area giving access to many different points of the lake and providing beautiful views of the area. Visitors can explore miles of these beautiful hiking and biking trails which meander along the 18,000-acre Stonewall Jackson Wildlife Management Area.

Remember to share the trail!

8281.description: A major recreation area is located at the Stonewall Jackson State Park which provides visitors with numerous opportunities including a 374 slip marina, picnic facilities and a 18 hole championship golf course, lodge, cabins and additional campsites. Backwater areas provide excellent fishing opportunities. Canoeists and other paddlers can explore the many inlets and backwater areas along the lake&#146;s 82-mile shoreline.

6235.name: Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Site

activities.name: Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Site
activities.description:
The Bridge can be enjoyed close up by hiking down the trail or driving to the traffic island on which it is preserved. In the area surrounding the Engine House are places for demonstrations of period work skills.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6235.directions: The park is located just off U.S. Route 22 approximately 12 miles west of Altoona and 10 miles east of Ebensburg. Take the Gallitzin Exit and turn right, following the signs. Visitors prior to 1992 accessed the park in other ways, but the GALLITZIN EXIT of US Route 22 is now the way to access the visitor center and historic area.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6236.name: Fort Necessity National Battlefield

activities.name: Fort Necessity National Battlefield
activities.description:
Five miles of hiking trails lead through forest and meadows around Fort Necessity. Cross-country skiing is available in winter. The trails are not groomed. Trails lead through forest and meadows around Fort Necessity. There is also a loop trail at Jumonville Glen and a short walking path at Braddock's Grave.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6236.directions: The main unit of the park is located 11 miles east of Uniontown, Pennsylvania on U.S. Highway 40. The visitor center, reconstructed Fort Necessity, Mount Washington Tavern and picnic area are located in the main unit of the park.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6237.name: Friendship Hill National Historic Site

activities.name: Friendship Hill National Historic Site
activities.description:
The ten miles of trails at Friendship Hill National Historic Site offer a glimpse of the natural world of the Allegheny Plateau.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6237.directions: From Downtown Pittsburgh:US 51 south to Uniontown US 119 South to Point Marion. PA 166 north - Park entrance is on left 3 miles north of Point Marion.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6238.name: Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site

activities.name: Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site
activities.description:
Walk the many miles of blazed trails and historic roadways that travel through Hopewell and neighboring French Creek State Park.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6238.directions: From the North: US Route 422 to PA Route 345. Turn onto Route 345 South and travel 6.6 miles through the town of Birdsboro and French Creek State Park until you reach the park entrance. <br /><br />From the East: PA Turnpike (I-76) West to exit 312 (Downingtown). Take PA Route 100 North 9 miles to PA Route 23.  Turn left onto Route 23 West and travel 7 miles to PA Route 345. Turn right onto Route 345 North 4 miles to the park entrance.<br /><br />From the South: I-95 North to PA Turnpike (I-76). PA Turnpike West to exit 312 (Downingtown). Take PA Route 100 North and travel 9 miles to PA Route 23. Turn left onto Route 23 West and travel 7 miles to PA Route 345. Turn right onto Route 345 North and travel 4 miles to the park entrance.<br /><br />From the West: PA Turnpike (I-76) East to exit 298 (Morgantown). Turn onto PA Route 10 South and travel 1 mile to PA Route 23. Turn left onto Route 23 East and travel 5.3 miles to PA Route 345. Turn left onto Route 345 North and travel 4 miles to the park entrance.<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

6239.name: Valley Forge National Historical Park

activities.name: Valley Forge National Historical Park
activities.description:
The park contains 19.5 miles of designated, marked, hiking trails. The 6.6 mile Joseph Plumb Martin Trail connects the key historic and interpretive sites. The Horseshoe Trail begins near Washington's Headquarters and runs to the Appalachian Trail. Other hiking trails include such footpaths as the relatively flat River and Valley Creek trails, and the hilly trails on Mount Joy and Mount Misery. In addition, hiking is permitted in most open areas of the park. While hiking in the park please keep your pets on a leash at all times.<br />
Source: National Park Service

6239.directions: From I-76 Schuylkill Expressway west: I-76 Schuylkill Expressway west to Exit 328A Stay Right and merge onto US 422 west Take Valley Forge exit onto Route 23 west Turn left at exit ramp and merge to the center lane Park entrance is straight through the first set of traffic lights (at intersection with N. Gulph Road)<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

24592.name: Norristown Farm Park

activities.name: Norristown Farm State Park
activities.description: Hiking, jogging, running, roller blading, skating, dog walking

24592.directions: West Germantown Pike<br />and Barley Sheaf Drive<br />2500 Upper Farm Road<br />Norristown, PA 19403<br />Ph: 610-270-0215
24592.description: Norristown Farm Park has a variety of buildings and open fields that represent a diverse history of farming, manufacturing and institutional associations. The buildings date from the mid-18th century through the early 20th century and at various times were part of mills, a tannery, farms and the Norristown State hospital. The unique and breath-taking beauty of the woods and agricultural fields, combined with a stocked trout stream, the Norristown Farm Park has it all.

18532.name: Dismal Swamp State Park

activities.name: Dismal Swamp State Park
activities.description:
Feel your daily stresses melt away as you cross the historic Dismal Swamp Canal and walk along the 2000-foot boardwalk into this geological wonder. Experience first hand the lush swamp forest and get up-close and personal with the wide variety of wildlife.<br />
For the adventurer, there are 18 miles of hiking and mountain biking trails, some along former logging roads. Or, enjoy a leisurely paddle down the Dismal Swamp Canal in your canoe or kayak.

18532.description:
Feel your daily stresses melt away as you cross the historic Dismal Swamp Canal and walk along the 2000-foot boardwalk into this geological wonder. Experience first hand the lush swamp forest and get up-close and personal with the wide variety of wildlife.

For the adventurer, there are 18 miles of hiking and mountain biking trails. Or, enjoy a leisurely paddle down the Dismal Swamp Canal in your canoe or kayak.

8293.name: Sutton Lake

activities.name: Sutton Lake
activities.description: Sutton Lake, in Sutton, WV is a popular destination for water sport lovers. Sutton Lake has over 40 miles of shoreline so there is plenty of space to have a good time and activities here include hiking, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

8293.directions: Take Interstate 79 to exit 64, the Sutton/Gassaway exit, follow signs to Sutton Dam (North on Route 4).
8293.description: Sutton Lake, in Sutton, WV is a popular destination for water sport lovers. Sutton Lake has over 40 miles of shoreline so there is plenty of space to have a good time and activities here include hiking, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

18535.name: Falls Lake State Recreation Area

activities.name: Falls Lake State Recreation Area
activities.description:
Falls Lake Trail will eventually travel the entire south shore of the lake. A portion of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail, the trail will connect two recreational areas and provide camping for backpackers. Portions of the trail travel through state parkland where all state park regulations apply. The remainder of the trail travels through N.C. Wildlife Resource Commission gamelands. For your safety, wear blaze orange while hiking this trail during hunting season.

A one-mile loop trail at B. W. Wells passes the naturalist's home and an interpretive area. Short trails at Rolling View and Sandling Beach allow a closer look at the aquatic environment. There are also short trails at Beaverdam and Holly Point.

18535.description: Hours of relaxation await you at Falls Lake State Recreation Area. Just moments away from the hustle and bustle of the city, Falls Lake is a great way to escape urban life. With a 12,000-acre lake and 26,000 acres of woodlands, Falls Lake State Recreation Area offers a choice of recreation areas Beaverdam, B.W. Wells, Highway 50, Holly Point, Rolling View, Sandling Beach and Shinleaf.

14443.name: Laurel Ridge Loop Trail (Georgia)

activities.name: Laurel Ridge Loop Trail
activities.description:
Park Hours: Visitor Center, 8 AM - 5 PM Gate opens at 7 AM<br />
LAUREL RIDGE TRAIL<br />
Located adjacent to our Visitor Center, this interpretive trail is a moderate 1.6-mile loop that climbs to Laurel Ridge and provides a seasonal view of Mt. Yonah.

14443.directions: From downtown Helen head north on Ga. Highway 75 about 1 mile to the junction with Ga. Highway Alt. 75. Turn left across a bridge and travel 2.6 miles to the stone entrance to Smithgall Woods - Dukes Creek Conservation Area. Turn left into the entrance and then turn left at the second driveway to reach the Visitor Center parking lot<br /><br />61 Tsalaki Trail, Helen, GA (706) 878-3087  gastateparks.org

14446.name: Vineyard Mountain Eagle Scout Trail (Georgia)

activities.name: Vineyard Mountain Eagle Scout Trail
activities.description:
Trail Length:<br />
Yellow Trailblaze - 2.8 Difficulty: Intermediate <br />
Trail Description: A system made up of three different trails. The yellow blaze that leads through the mature wooded shoreline of Lake Allatoona

14446.directions: Directions: From Canton, Take Ga. 20 to I75. Go South on 75 to Red Top Mtn Rd. (Exit 285). Trailhead on left before Bethany Bridge<br /><br />Trailhead: Red Top Mtn. Road near Bethany Bridge<br /><br /><br /><br />Nearest City: Cartersville

18109.name: Norvin Green State Forest

activities.name: Norvin Green State Forest
activities.description: A system of marked hiking trails are available for the public to explore. These trails offer visitors opportunities to hike interior woodlands and rocky vistas. There are no multi-use trails available in the park.

18109.directions: Take Route 287 to exit 57, follow Skyline Drive to Greenwood Lake Turnpike to West Brook Road to Snake Den Road. Follow signs to Weis Ecology Center. Parking is available at Weis Ecology Center or along Burnt Meadow Road and Glen Wild Road.
18109.description: The undisturbed forest and rugged terrain of Norvin Green offers sanctuary for birds and other wildlife. Part of the Wyanokie Wilderness Area, the forest is near Wanaque Reservoir and is home to an extensive trail system built from old logging roads. Several trails link up with public and private facilities, including the Weis Ecology Center and reservoir property. The existing trails, either old forest roads or new trails constructed by volunteers, are perfect for nature walks and other outdoor classroom activities. With hills ranging from 400 to 1,300 feet in elevation, Norvin Green provides the avid hiker with scenic vistas, including the New York skyline, Burnt Meadow Brook and Lake Sonoma. The property is accessible by foot only.

18544.name: Jockey's Ridge State Park

activities.name: Jockey's Ridge State Park
activities.description: Both children and adults enjoy climbing and playing on the park's huge pile of sand. Some hike the dune for the spectacular views of coastal Carolina, others for the experience of the desert-like environment. When hiking the ridge, look for fulgurites, glass tubes formed when lightning hits the sand. (Please don't remove the fulgurites from the park.)

18544.description:
There are many reasons why millions of people visit Jockey's Ridge State Park. Some come to see the tallest sand dune on the Atlantic coast; others come for the spectacular sunsets.

At Jockey's Ridge State Park you can experience the world of the desert. Shifting sands, high winds, extreme temperatures and a lack of water make the park resemble barren environments such as the Sahara Desert. You also can explore the wonders of an estuarine environment. The tidal waters of the Roanoke Sound, the western boundary of the park, is a rich habitat for a variety of plant and animal life, making these waters the source of much of the sea's bounty.

6259.name: Brooker Creek Preserve/ Education Center Loop

activities.name: Brooker Creek Preserve/ Education Center Loop
activities.description: This is a very large preserve in Pinellas County which also features a really nice environmental and education center. It encompasses 8,700 square acres of land. There are several hiking and equestrian trails. The Education Center Loop Trail is 0.7 miles long and can be accessed from the Education Center. The trail consists of mainly raised boardwalks and sand. There are also interpretive trail signs found along the way to highlight points of interest.

6259.directions: From South Tampa:  <br /><br />Follow the Courtney Campbell Causeway (SR 60) west and turn north (right) onto McMullen Booth Road (CR 611).  The name of this road changes to East Lake Road north of Tampa Road (CR 752).  Continue north to Keystone Road (CR 582) and turn east (right).  Travel approximately 2.5 miles to the Brooker Creek Preserve Environmental Education Center entrance.  Follow the one-mile drive to the parking area.<br /><br /><br /><br />From north Tampa: <br /><br />From N Dale Mabry Hwy (SR 597), turn west (left) onto Van Dyke Road (CR 685A) and travel to Gunn Hwy (CR 587).  Turn north (right) and continue 1.4 miles to Tarpon Springs Road (CR 582).  Turn west (left) and travel approximately 5.1 miles to the Brooker Creek Environmental Education Center entrance.  Follow the one-mile drive to the parking area.<br /><br /><br /><br />From Pinellas County:  <br /><br />Go north on US 19 to Tarpon Avenue E. (CR 582), turn east (right).  Pass through the traffic signal at East Lake Road (CR 611) and continue for approximately 2.5 miles to the Brooker Creek Preserve Environmental Education Center entrance.  Follow the one-mile drive to the center.

10359.name: Cape Henlopen State Park

activities.name: Cape Henlopen State Park
activities.description:
Cape Henlopen SP is known for its pristine beaches, specifically its two lifeguarded designated swimming beaches. The park has nearby food and drink choices, showers, restrooms and a picnic pavilion. Golfing, basketball and hunting are permitted in some areas of the park. Hiking, swimming, camping, horseback riding and biking are also popular activities here. The park offers eight trails of different difficulty and beauty. Some of these trails can also be used for horseback riding and biking.

The Beach Trail: 4.6 miles- hiking and equestrian- easy to moderate.
Pinelands Trail: 2 miles- hiking- easy.
Seaside Nature Trail: 0.6 miles- hiking- easy.
Walking Dunes Trail: 1.6 miles- hiking and biking- easy.
Salt Marsh Spur: 0.6 miles- hiking and biking- easy.
Gordons Pond Trail: 2.75 miles- hiking and biking- easy to moderate.
Bike Loop Trail: 3 miles- shared use- easy to moderate.
Junction and Breakwater Trail: 5 miles- shared use- easy.

10359.directions: Ocean City, MD - 30 Miles Rehoboth Beach, DE - 7 Miles Baltimore, MD/Washington, DC/Philidelphia, PA 120 Miles  Traveling South on DE Route 1, follow signs to US Route 9 East.  Turn left onto Dartmouth Road to stop sign. Turn left again onto Route 9 East, Freeman Highway, traveling approximately 2.8 miles. Turn right onto Cape Henlopen Drive.  Park entrance is approximately 1 mile past the Cape May-Lewes Ferry terminal.
10359.description: Cape Henlopen SP is known for its pristine beaches, specifically its two lifeguarded designated swimming beaches. The park has nearby food and drink choices, showers, restrooms and a picnic pavilion. Golfing, basketball and hunting are permitted in some areas of the park. Hiking, swimming, camping, horseback riding and biking are also popular activities here.

activities.name: Appalachian Trail: Maryland
activities.description: The Appalachian Trail runs 41 miles through Maryland, from the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3335/West-Virginia/Appalachian-Trail--West-Virginia.html">West Virginia</a> border to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3318/Pennsylvania/Appalachian-Trail--Pennsylvania.html">Pennsylvania</a> border. To get more detailed information about each section of the trail in Maryland, please click on the individual trail listings below.

18554.name: Merchants Millpond State Park

activities.name: Merchants Millpond State Park
activities.description:
Merchants Millpond State Park is the home of aged cypress trees, spanish moss and a coastal swamp area. This is one of North Carolina's rarest ecological communities. Canoeing, fishing, camping, picnicking and hiking through the enchanting area are all popular activities here.<br />
The park offers nine miles of trail with a variety of habitats. Merchants Millpond is heavily infested with ticks during warm weather months; be cautious while hiking. Insect repellent may help prevent a tick bite and the possibility of disease.

18554.description: Merchants Millpond State Park is the home of aged cypress trees, spanish moss and a coastal swamp area. This is one of North Carolina's rarest ecological communities. Canoeing, fishing, camping, picnicking and hiking through the enchanting area are all popular activities here.

10363.name: Lums Pond State Park

activities.name: Lums Pond State Park
activities.description: The Lums Pond State Park features the largest freshwater pond in Delaware. It consists of 1,790 acres, 200 of which make up the actual Lums Pond. The park is a popular place for fishing, hiking, picnicking and sports, however swimming is prohibited. There are several picnic locations throughout the park in addition to three large pavilions. Lums Pond SP also has ball fields and game courts for a variety of sports from baseball and softball to soccer and tennis, among others. There is also a large campground on the site for year round camping.  Hikers are given the opportunity to explore many scenic views and habitats along the 7.5 mile Swamp Forest Trail that circles the pond. Lums Pond SP also features over 10 miles of multi-purpose trails (horses, bikes, hikers, and snowmobiles).

10363.directions: Elkton, MD:  5 miles Dover, DE:  30 miles Wilmington, DE:  15 miles Baltimore, MD:  50 miles Philadelphia, PA:  40 miles  From the North:  take I-95 South to exit 1A (Middletown & 896 South) about 8 miles to Rt. 71/301.  Turn left onto Rt. 71/301.  Go northeast about 1 mile.  Campground is on the left.  From the South:  take 896/301 North.  Go over Summit Bridge.  At the bottom of Summit Bridge turn right onto Rt. 71/301.  Go northeast about 1 mile.  Campground is on the left.
10363.description: The Lums Pond State Park features the largest freshwater pond in Delaware. It consists of 1,790 acres, 200 of which make up the actual Lums Pond. The park is a popular place for fishing, hiking, picnicking and sports, however swimming is prohibited. There are several picnic locations throughout the park in addition to three large pavilions. Lums Pond SP also has ball fields and game courts for a variety of sports from baseball and softball to soccer and tennis, among others. There is also a large campground on the site for year round camping.

10364.name: Trap Pond State Park

activities.name: Trap Pond State Park
activities.description: Trap Pond State Park is home to a remaining beautifully preserved portion of a freshwater wetlands that was once in the area. Visitors are welcome to partake in the many opportunities available to explore the 4.9-mile Boundary hiking trails surrounding the pond and wetland forest. During a visit, birdwatching, boating and fishing are all easy to access and popular activities at the park. The park also offers picnic tables, volleyball courts, playgrounds and horseshoe pits for your enjoyment.

10364.directions: Trap Pond State Park is located at 33587 Baldcypress Lane, Laurel, DE 19956.
10364.description: Trap Pond State Park is home to a remaining beautifully preserved portion of a freshwater wetlands that was once in the area. Visitors are welcome to partake in the many opportunities available to explore the 4.9-mile Boundary hiking trails surrounding the pond and wetland forest. During a visit, birdwatching, boating and fishing are all easy to access and popular activities at the park. The park also offers picnic tables, volleyball courts, playgrounds and horseshoe pits for your enjoyment.

18559.name: Occoneechee Mountain State Natural Area

activities.name: Occoneechee Mountain
activities.description: Amazing pocket of nature near the nexis of I-85 and I-40.  You may have seen the mountain with the tower on top near the interstate but you really have to hike around to really appreciate the area.  Wide gravel road leads to the top with several hiking trails to take you beside the river and small fishing ponds.  Be sure to check out the overlook, a nearly shear cliff face that is probably 100-200 feet high.  Top elevation is 867 feet.

18559.directions: (919) 383-1686<br />eno.river@ncparks.gov<br />Physical: 625 Virginia Cates Road, , Mailing: 6101 Cole Mill Road, Durham, NC 27705-9275<br />GPS: 36.060835, -79.116900
18559.description: High scenic views and mountain trails await you at Occoneechee Mountain State Natural Area. This Piedmont monadnock has been recognized as one of the most important natural areas in the Triangle. It is the highest point in Orange County at 867 feet, and the oak forest, pond, field, heath bluff, and river habitats found on the mountain support species that are rare and significant in this region. With 190 acres of land and nearly three miles of trails, visitors can experience a wide variety of the area's natural surroundings and wildlife.

18560.name: Pettigrew State Park

activities.name: Pettigrew State Park
activities.description:
Beginning at the park office, a one-mile section winds past the campground and Somerset Place. After wandering through a sweetgum forest, the trail leads to Bee Tree Overlook, a wooden platform offering a view of the lake and a place to observe wintering waterfowl. Between the site of Bonarva and the canal is a short trail leading to Pettigrew Family Cemetery.<br />
Moccasin Trail leads northwest from the park office for approximately three miles to Moccasin Canal. After traveling through a cypress and hardwood forest, the trail stops at a 350-foot boardwalk, which cuts through a cypress swamp to Moccasin Overlook. This view of Big Point is one of the most impressive vistas in the area. Morotoc Trail continues from the overlook to Cypress Point. Bicycles are allowed on most of the park trails.<br />
The Pocosin Natural Area has a short trail to an observation tower and carnivorous plant management area. See the park map for distance and difficulty.

18560.description: With more than 5,000 acres of land around Lake Phelps and the Scuppernong River including over 16,600 acres of water, Pettigrew State Park is an ideal blend of nature, history and recreation.

18112.name: Princeton Battlefield State Park

activities.name: Princeton Battlefield State Park
activities.description: Adjacent to the park, the Institute Woods is comprised of a 588 acre mixed hardwood, wetlands and agricultural land with a variety of trails. Most trails are level to slightly graded. There are no specific ADA trails but many level trails.

18112.directions: Located on Mercer Road (Princeton Pike). 1.5 miles south of Princeton University and 3.8 miles north of Interstate 295/95.
18112.description: On January 3, 1777, the peaceful winter fields and woods of Princeton Battlefield were transformed into the site of what is considered to be the fiercest fight of its size during the American Revolution. During this desperate battle, American troops under General George Washington surprised and defeated a force of British Regulars. Coming at the end of "The Ten Crucial Days" which saw the well-known night crossing of the Delaware River and two battles in Trenton, the Battle of Princeton gave Washington his first victory against the British Regulars on the field. The battle extended over a mile away to the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University).

4226.name: Natchez Trace

activities.name: Natchez Trace
activities.description: Natchez Trace features 7 miles of hiking trails near Tupelo, MS.

4226.directions: From Hwy78 take the natchez trace exit travel south toward Jackson. Turn in at Chickasaw Village and trail head is located at the edge of woodline.

4096.name: Big Bear Lake

activities.name: Big Bear Lake
activities.description: Big Bear Lake features 25 miles of hiking trails near Hazelton, WV.

4096.directions: Exit off I-68 east of Morgantown WV at the Hazelton exit and go south a few miles to Big Bear Lake.   This is a private resort area, however bikers are welcome.  Cost is $5.00 per day or if you ride there often you can obtain a season pass.  A waiver has to be signed and a trail map is provided at that time.   There are several suggested rides with something for all abilities.   Check their website for open dates.  They close during hunting seasons.

18113.name: Ramapo Mountain State Forest

activities.name: Ramapo Mountain State Forest
activities.description: An system of marked hiking and multi use trails are available for the public to explore. These trails offer visitors opportunities to hike interior woodlands and rocky vistas.

18113.directions: Take Route 287 to exit 57, follow Skyline Drive to parking lot on the left
18113.description: This hilly forest is a sanctuary for wildlife. Hikers and mountain bikers enjoy miles of challenging trails. Many trails offer a view of the New York City skyline. Birdwatchers are attracted to the forest for its ponds, streams and marshes that provide the perfect habitat for bird and other wildlife species. The forest borders the Ramapo Mountain Reservation, which is part of the Bergen County Park System.

6281.name: Day Loop off of the Volunteer Trail

activities.name: Day Loop off of the Volunteer Trail
activities.description: This is a wonderful fairly easy 4 mile loop which winds around the lake and through the woods. It's great any time of the year and is a great place to view fauna and flora.

6281.directions: From Nashville, take I-40 East to Mt. Juliet Road, Exit 226-A. Turn right onto TN-171 S/N Mt Juliet Rd	which turns into Hobson Pike. Turn right onto Bakers Grove Ln (If you reach the actual entrance to Long Hunter State Park, you've gone too far). Take the 1st left onto Granny Wright Ln which dead ends at the trail head.

4241.name: C&O Canal

activities.name: C&o Canal
activities.description: C&o Canal features 183 miles of hiking trails near Washington, AK.

4241.directions: The trail terminates at two points; Washington DC at Georgetown (27th and M NW), and Cumberland Maryland on the other end.  Depending on where you're starting, use mapquest or similar service.

4242.name: Fort Circle Trail From Fort Dupont Park

activities.name: Fort Circle Trail From Fort Dupont Park
activities.description: Fort Circle Trail From Fort Dupont Park features 8 miles of hiking trails near Washington, VA.

4242.directions: From I-395, I-295, or Capitol Hill, take Pennsylvania Ave east into Anacostia, turning left at Minnesota Ave SE. Go just over half a mile and turn right when you see a large open grassy area. This is Randle Circle. Go almost 180 degrees around the circle before turning right onto Fort Dupont Drive. There is a National Park Service sign reading ìFort Dupont Parkî at this turn. The parking lot is just ahead on the left, with a sign that says ìFort Dupont Activity Center.î

18115.name: Ringwood State Park

activities.name: Ringwood State Park
activities.description: Excellent variety of trails.

18115.directions: Take Route 287 to exit 57, follow signs to Ringwood State Park.
18115.description: Dedicated in 1984, the garden is the culmination of two eras of landscape architecture under the direction of Francis Lynde Stetson, owner of Skylands from 1891-1922. The garden contains an extensive variety of plants, evergreens and deciduous trees and shrubs in specialty areas. Of particular interest are the crabapple vista, terraced gardens, perennial and annual gardens and woodland paths. The extensive vistas of the garden and veiw of Ramapo Mountains frame this 96-acre botanical showplace. Visitors can tour the gardens and surrounding woods year round, from 8 am to 8 pm.

4121.name: Tea Creek Mountain Trail

activities.name: Tea Creek Mountain Trail
activities.description: Tea Creek Mountain Trail features 5 miles of hiking trails near Slatyfork, WV.

4121.directions: Take Rt.219 south of Elkins, WV for about an hour.  Just south of the little community of Slatyfork, WV turn onto Rt.150 (Scenic Highway).  In a few miles when you start off the mountain you will pass Gauley Mtn. Trail on right, then you will see Little Laurel overlook on your left.  Immediately on your right is parking for Tea Creek Mtn. Trail or others.  We always park at the overlook.

4122.name: Gauley-bearpen-boundary-shoals-loop

activities.name: Gauley-bearpen-boundary-shoals-loop
activities.description: Gauley-bearpen-boundary-shoals-loop features 17 miles of hiking trails near Slatyfork, WV.

4122.directions: Slatyfork is located a few miles south of Snowshoe on 219, however keep going south of Slatyfork to the top of the mountain and take Rt.150 (Scenic Hwy).  Go around till you start off the mountain.  You will see Little Laurel overlook on your left in this direction.  This is where this ride starts unless you don't have a shuttle.  If you have shuttle, drive it to the bottom of the mountain, turn onto Williams River Rd. and take a left down the river.  Tea Creek Campground will be on your right in about 1/2 mile.  Cross the bridge into campground and park on your right.  The loop will bring you out on the road straight ahead as you cross the bridge.  Leave vehicle here and drive other to the overlook on Rt.150.

18117.name: Spruce Run Recreation Area

activities.name: Spruce Run Recreation Area
activities.description: The Highlands Millennium Trail, which will eventually connect the Delaware River to the Hudson River, is approximately 0.91 miles (one way) within the park boundaries. This leisurely hike is not ADA accessible. The park grounds and roadways are excellent areas for other strolling, jogging and biking activities.

18117.directions: From the intersections of Interstate 78W and Route 31N, follow 31 north to the third traffic light - Van Syckels Road. Turn left and continue 1.5 miles to the Park entrance which is on the left.
18117.description: Surrounded by the rolling hills of Hunterdon County, Spruce Run Recreation Area is popular with picnickers, swimmers, fishermen, boaters and campers. The reservoir was one of the first water supply facilities to be constructed and operated by the state and covers 1,290 acres with 15 miles of shoreline for recreation. Spruce Run is the third largest reservoir in the state after Round Valley and Wanaque reservoirs.

4124.name: Black Bear Loop Greenbrier State Forest

activities.name: Black Bear Loop Greenbrier State Forest
activities.description: Black Bear Loop Greenbrier State Forest is a 5 mile hiking trail in White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia.

4124.directions: From I-64 take the White Sulphur Springs Exit and follow the signs for the <br /><br />Greenbrier State Forest. Drive past the ranger station about 1-2 miles to the <br /><br />picnic area parking lot just past the campgrounds. You can park there, or park <br /><br />farther up the road near the Frisbee Golf course and start on Old Fields Trail. <br /><br />There are several ways to connect these loops. This is just one possible <br /><br />connection.

6318.name: Johnson Ferry Trail (Georgia)

activities.name: Johnson Ferry Trail
activities.description:
Park section in Cobb County. Johnson Ferry North has 2.5 miles of trails that are excellent for viewing plants and wildlife. There is a boat launch and a covered pavilion to relax after a hike. Activities: Walking trail and boat ramp. Amenities: Parking, picnic tables, restrooms.<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
<br />
Venue Type: Park / Nature Preserve <br />
<br />
Hours: The park is open from dawn to dusk. Dawn is defined as 30 minutes before legal sunrise and dusk is defined as 30 minutes after legal sunset. For day use only.

6318.directions: Chattahoochee River NRA Johnson Ferry North <br /><br /><br /><br />301 Johnson Ferry Rd., Marietta, GA, 30068 <br /><br /><br /><br />(678) 538-1200 - Venue Website

18121.name: Voorhees State Park

activities.name: Voorhees State Park
activities.description: Voorhees has 7 trails that are suitable for a wide range of abilities and interests. All trails in the park are multi-use except the Cross Park Trail and the Parcourse Circuit, which are footpaths only. The trails range from wide and graveled to rocky and steep in places; the parcourse is accessible for people with disabilities.

18121.directions: From New York or north Jersey: Take Route 78 west to exit 17, merge with Route 31 north. At second traffic light, make a right onto 513 north through High Bridge. Follow signs to the park.
18121.description: Voorhees, like Parvin State Park, served as a camp for the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) - Franklin Roosevelt's program to get people back to work during the Depression. The CCC planted trees and constructed shelters, picnic sites and trails throughout the park. Two overlooks provide scenic views of Round Valley Reservoir and Spruce Run Reservoir.

6338.name: Creek Hollow (Foxfire Mountain) Tennessee

activities.name: Creek Hollow
activities.description: A great unique hiking experience with Llama's.State Licensed and Insured Year 'Round Hiking, Possible Limitations in Winter Age Limits: 6-75 years old. All guides are CPR/Emergency First Aid trained by the American Red Cross to ensure your safety along your wilderness experience.

6338.directions: 1839 Creek Hollow Way Sevierville, TN 37876. Foxfire Mountain Steve Garrett<br /><br />Smoky Mountain Llama Treks<br /><br />llamahiking@gmx.com<br /><br />(423) 487-0600 Office <br /><br />(616) 430-0775 Cell

25291.name: Big Brook Park

activities.name: Big Brook Park
activities.description: Big Brook Park is a mosaic of habitats, the most significant of which is the extensive grassland covering the rolling landscape. Many field edges are mowed, providing additional unmarked trail experiences.

25291.description: Big Brook Park is a mosaic of habitats, the most significant of which is the extensive grassland covering the rolling landscape. Many field edges are mowed, providing additional unmarked trail experiences.

21619.name: Conemaugh River Lake

activities.name: Conemaugh River Lake
activities.description: Conemaugh River Lake has an unusual endowment of cultural resources which works to attract visitors to this Pennsylvanian park. This is a popular destination for all ages as there is hiking and plenty of picnic space to enjoy all day long!

21619.directions: Follow signs 7 miles east from Saltsburg. <br />Conemaugh River Lake<br />U.S. Army Corps of Engineers<br />RD2,Box 131<br />Saltsburg, PA 15681-9544<br />Phone: (724) 459-7240
21619.description: Conemaugh River Lake has an unusual endowment of cultural resources which works to attract visitors to this Pennsylvanian park. This is a popular destination for all ages as there is hiking and plenty of picnic space to enjoy all day long!

18643.name: Shawnee State Park

activities.name: Shawnee State Park
activities.description: 6 hiking trails
